awd_titl_txt: Laminar to Turbulent Transition in Pipe Flow:  Effect of Dispersed Phase
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Longmire, Ellen
Proposal Number: 1605719

The goal of the proposed research is to experimentally and theoretically explore the transition from laminar to turbulent flow in the case of two phase flow in a pipe. While a lot of prior work has been done on transition for single phase fluids, the theme of this proposal is largely unexplored. The proposed work will have an impact on understanding the fundamental notions in transition to turbulence when one of the two phases is dispersed in the other. The technological applications of this work are important, most notably in the process of 3D printing and in additive manufacturing.

Recent experiments on pipe flows suggest that the critical Reynolds number for transition can either be shifted to significantly lower values or delayed to much higher values when a liquid flow includes a second phase of immiscible liquid drops or rigid particles. The direction of the shift depends on the volume fraction of the discrete phase as well as the ratio of pipe-to-particle diameter. The physical mechanisms behind these transition changes are unknown. The objective of the proposed research is to uncover and characterize these mechanisms through experimentation and analysis. It is hypothesized that at least two mechanisms are present: larger drops or particles can promote instabilities caused by local differences between the particle and surrounding fluid velocity, and smaller drops or particles can suppress growth of or otherwise disrupt larger scale instabilities and coherent structures. Experiments are planned in a transparent pipe facility where critical Reynolds number will be determined for liquid/liquid and liquid/solid dispersions. Results will be analyzed to determine time evolving flow features, ensemble averaged statistics, and dynamically significant modes associated with transitional flow structures, and ultimately the specific mechanisms affecting transition. The educational activities proposed include undergraduate and graduate student involvement in research, engagement with elementary school teachers to develop science curriculum, and outreach activities ranging from actively mentoring female high school and college students to meetings of the PI with members of Congress in order to promote science and engineering.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Laminar to Turbulent Transition in Pipe Flow:  Effect of Dispersed Phase

 Recent experiments on pipe flows suggested that the critical Reynolds number, or level of flow inertia, for transition can either be shifted to significantly lower values or delayed to much higher values when a liquid flow includes a second phase of immiscible liquid drops or rigid particles.  The direction of the shift depends on the volume fraction of the discrete phase as well as the ratio of pipe-to-particle diameter D/d.  The objective of the proposed research was to determine and characterize the physical mechanisms causing these changes through experimentation and analysis.

Intellectual Merit:

A transparent pipe facility was developed to accommodate flows of neutrally buoyant particles in a transitional regime.  Turbulent puff structures, the first evidence of transition from laminar to turbulent conditions, were sensed by measuring associated pressure pulses related to temporary increases in friction.  The three-dimensional nature and organization of these intermittent structures were characterized. Planar cross sections of velocity vectors were captured in rapid succession and reconstructed into three-dimensional volumes. An image processing method was developed to identify the trailing edge and azimuthal orientation of puff structures to obtain meaningful ensemble averaged statistics and dynamically-significant modes.  These results and statistics represent a unique and comprehensive database with well-documented initial conditions useful for modelers. 

Side view and end-on imaging methods were developed and employed to quantify particle concentration distribution and velocity over the pipe cross section.  The results demonstrated that larger particles, which tended to concentrate near the wall in laminar flow, promoted more frequent puff formation at a given Reynolds number rather than changing the nature of the puffs themselves. The puffs acted to redistribute particles away from walls, and the redistribution was long lasting, associated with a passage distance of up to 160D.  Particle wall-normal velocities were significant over a relatively limited streamwise range of 10D associated with the most turbulent section of puffs while streamwise velocity disturbances were significant over longer ranges of 40D.  It is thought that the long lasting disturbances act to destabilize laminar flow and therefore act to increase the number of transitional structures. 

Broad Impact: 

A key outcome of the investigation included development of novel experimental techniques that allowed investigation of detailed interactive effects in multi-phase flows. Such methods can be employed in many additional physical regimes and applications.  The knowledge gained about transition in multi-phase flows can be used to advantage across a broad range of applications. Transition from the laminar to turbulent regime, whether in external or internal flows, has been notoriously difficult to predict with accuracy.  The improved understanding of the dynamics related to discrete particle effects on growth or damping of transitional structures will lead to improved model concepts that incorporate these effects. Improved knowledge and predictability of transition ranges will lead to increased consistency and efficiency in materials transport, extension of operating limits of existing facilities and systems, and additive manufacturing and materials processing systems with novel capabilities.  

Two graduate students were trained on this project, and multiple undergraduates participated in the research through REU supplements and the UM UROP program. A post-doctoral researcher made significant contributions to the experimental and processing methods developed.  Prior to the onset of Covid in 2020, the PI also worked directly each summer with middle school students attending the Minnesota Aviation Career Education (ACE) Camp. Additional outreach activities included mentoring female high school students considering engineering careers, giving lab tours to groups of students from junior high to undergrad level, and participating on mentoring panels for women and minority scholars from undergraduate to tenure-track level.

 


Last Modified: 01/17/2022
Modified by: Ellen Longmire
